rules.title: <info>
rules.abstract: <info> provides details that help users complete the actions stated in <cmd>. For example, they may document form fields or display a screen capture. They may also provide notes, tips, warnings or details about exceptions that may occur.

rule.rule-statement: Use <info> only when it creates value. Most steps do not require supporting information.
When documenting a form, define only non-trivial items.
Do not itemize options from drop-down lists unless you intend to help the user select the correct one.
rule.justification: Users can read the values in the interface.

rule.rule-statement: Do not include screen captures unless they add value.

ul.li: Users are in front of the tool. They can see the page, the controls, the forms.
You can name the controls that change in <stepresult> to help users confirm that they are on the right track.
Confronting 3 pages of instructions is scary, half a page seems doable.
On smaller devices, such as phones or tablets, viewing large images requires that users tilt their device, zoom in or scroll up and down.

li.p: Screen captures are hard on deadlines and costs as they are work intensive and can't be completed until the tool is ready. The domino effect is felt heavily on localization deadlines and costs.

examplefig.desc: This <stepresult> identifies the panel that opens by name, which eliminates the need to display large screen captures.
examplefig.codeblock: <step> <cmd>In the table of contents, right-click the slide to which you want to add the image and click <uicontrol>Add illustration...</uicontrol>.</cmd> <stepresult>The <uicontrol>Search image</uicontrol> panel opens.</stepresult> </step>
